is awarded for construction, alteration, or repair of any public building or public work of the United States, the prime Bond contractor must furnish a performance bond for contracts guaranteeing that of the Miller the work will be performed to completion. Refer to Section

) The provisions of the Miller Act apply only to taxes collected, deducted, or withheld from wages paid by the prime contractor and are not applicable to subcontractors. (

) This Section deals with the ability of the United States to reach assets may be or may have been disposed of by the taxpayer prior to assessment and which are or were not subject to the Federal tax lien. (
) Section
of IRM

, Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers, detailed information on recognizing whether a fraudulent conveyance and transferee liability may exist and the recourse available to the United States such situations. (

) There are three principal methods by which the United States may proceed where assets have been transferred in fraud of creditors. a. Setting aside fraudulent conveyances. b. Transferee liability by civil law suit. c. Transferee liability by notice of deficiency. (
) Of the above methods, assessments which can be obtained through notice deficiency should be looked to first. (

) The government’s case will be based primarily on the facts developed and reported by the revenue officer. It is essential that the investigation be and thoroughly conducted and the revenue officer’s report be as complete detailed as possible. (
) The revenue officer will prepare Form

, Report of Investigation of feree Liability, in triplicate and complete the following: a. Attach schedules and explanatory and descriptive statements for a clear and complete presentation of the facts. b. Attach documentary evidence, beginning with the year of transferor’s liability, of any nature which the revenue officer is able to secure in support of the determination of transferee liability. c. Forward Form
with attachments to the Group Manager. (
) The Group Manager will examine the report of investigation to ensure that it complete and that a proper basis exists for assertion of the transferee (

) Upon agreement with the recommendation, the Group Manager will: a. Sign and forward original, with attachments, by memorandum to and Special Programs in the Examination function. b. Retain a copy. c. Associate a copy with the transferor Bal Due case file.

This Section deals with the ability of the United States to reach assets which may be or may have been disposed of by the taxpayer prior to assessment and which are or were not subject to the Federal tax lien.
There are three principal methods by which the United States may proceed where assets have been transferred in fraud of creditors.
The revenue officer will prepare Form 3031, Report of Investigation of Trans- feree Liability, in triplicate and complete the following:
The Group Manager will examine the report of investigation to ensure that it is complete and that a proper basis exists for assertion of the transferee liability.
a. Sign and forward original, with attachments, by memorandum to and Special Programs in the Examination function. b. Retain a copy. c. Associate a copy with the transferor Bal Due case file.
Collection Techniques and Other Assignments 5.1.14

) The revenue officer who initiated the assertion of the transferee or is assigned multiple transferee assessments initiated by Examination or Officer as sustained by Appeals, will act as coordinator of the collection activity. of the (

) Multiple transferee assessments initiated by Examination or sustained by Activity Appeals will be identified by the coordinating Revenue Officer with the “Transferee assessments exceed transferor liability” in the Bal Due case history. (

) The revenue officer acting as coordinator (transferor revenue officer) will: a. Effect any required Bal Due account transfer. b. Work with Counsel on the application of payments between the and transferor. Note: The concept is similar to the cross referencing done with Trust Fund Recovery penalty collections. However, there are no cross-reference tions codes to cross apply funds, so even though these accounts are handled by non-masterfile, payment applications are not correctly When receiving payments on an IRC

assessment case, work with Advisory and Counsel on application and cross-referencing of those payments. c. Notify the holders of other related Bal Due accounts of credits to be sidered in further collection of the assessed liability upon receipt of the information. d. Suspend collection in the event the total of payments received from all related Bal Due accounts equals the total assessed liability. e. Work with Counsel to ensure that NFTL are released appropriately. (

Note: If payment is made by personal check, the abatement of any balance(s) of assessments will be held in abeyance until such check has cleared the on which drawn. (

) No abatement will be administratively made in those cases which are not involved in court proceedings unless the statutory period in which a refund claim may be brought has expired as to the transferee. (

) IRC
(a) provides that: (cid:
) Third parties who directly pay another’s payrolls can be held liable for full amount of taxes required to be withheld but not paid over to the ernment. (cid:
) Employers are not relieved of their responsibility to file required returns related documents (such as Forms W-
). See IRM
LRG for a sion of this subject. (
) IRC
(b) deals only with persons who supply funds to an employer for purpose of paying wages when two conditions exist. (cid:
) The person must know that the funds advanced are to be used for the payment of wages and, (cid:

) The supplier of funds must have “ actual notice or knowledge” at the such funds are advanced that the employer does not intend to, or will be able to make timely payment or deposit of the taxes required to be withheld. (
) Under IRC
(b) the liability of the third party may not exceed
% of the amount supplied the employer for the specific purpose of paying wages. However, a supplier of funds is liable (subject to the
% limitation) the as a third party who pays wages directly. The
% limitation includes any interest accrued on the unpaid taxes, therefore the Government cannot
% and then recover interest on that
%, but it can recover interest the
% limitation. (
) IRC
(c) provides that any amount paid to the United States pursuant to IRC

(a) and (b) shall be credited against the unpaid tax liability of the employer with respect to whose employees’ wages such amounts are due. However, employers are not relieved of their responsibility to file required returns and related documents (such as Forms W-
IRC 3505(b) deals only with persons who supply funds to an employer for the purpose of paying wages when two conditions exist.

withheld. Under IRC
(b) the liability of the third party may not exceed
% of the amount supplied the employer for the specific purpose of paying wages. However, a supplier of funds is liable (subject to the
% limitation) the same as a third party who pays wages directly. The
% limitation includes any interest accrued on the unpaid taxes, therefore the Government cannot
% and then recover interest on that
%, but it can recover interest within the
% limitation. IRC
(c) provides that any amount paid to the United States pursuant to IRC
(a) and (b) shall be credited against the unpaid tax liability of the

Under IRC 3505(b) the liability of the third party may not exceed 25% of the amount supplied the employer for the specific purpose of paying wages. However, a supplier of funds is liable (subject to the 25% limitation) the same as a third party who pays wages directly. The 25% limitation includes any interest accrued on the unpaid taxes, therefore the Government cannot 25% and then recover interest on that 25%, but it can recover interest within the 25% limitation.
However, employers are not relieved of their responsibility to file required returns and related documents (such as Forms W-2).
) In order to collect from a third party under Section
the United States must bring suit against the third party within ten years after the assessment of the tax against the employer. (

) In certain instances, revenue officers will be notified or otherwise informed that a third party is paying or supplying wages or has paid or supplied wages for Liability employer. Notification will usually be made by means of Form
, Statement Payments of Liability of Lender, Surety, or Other Person for Withholding Taxes. Form
may be received from the taxpayer or the third party. In other cases, Form
will be sent directly to the service center. In such cases, Form will be received from the service center or from Advisory. (

Collection Techniques and Other Assignments 5.1.14
) Where the facts indicate a third party is liable for all or a portion of the employment taxes, but the third party neglects or refuses to voluntarily pay amount of the liability under IRC
, the revenue officer must develop the facts to support a recommendation for civil suit and forward this tion to Advisory. (
) Facts which may support the liability of a third party under IRC

(a) the following: a. A written agreement between the employer of record and a third party which states that wages are to be paid directly by the third party. b. Net wages paid by a third party as evidenced by: (cid:
) Canceled checks of the third party (cid:
) Bank records of the third party (cid:
) Cash disbursements recorded in payroll records of the third party c. Payroll records of the employer involved are maintained or controlled the third party. d. Forms
and W-
have been prepared, signed, or filed by the party. (
) Facts which support the liability of a third party under IRC
(b) include following: a. A written agreement between the employer of record and the third party that net wages will be supplied by the third party. Internal Revenue Manual
Facts which support the liability of a third party under IRC 3505(b) include the
A written agreement between the employer of record and the third party that net wages will be supplied by the third party.

b. Records of the third party showing disbursements by cash or check to employer of record in amounts approximate to the wages subsequently paid to employees. c. Statements made by the employer and the third party indicate that the third party was aware of the amount of wages paid each payroll period. d. Statements indicate that the parties understood that the third party would be supplying funds to the taxpayer to pay wages. e. Payroll records of the employer involved are maintained or controlled by the third party. f. Forms
and W-
have been prepared, signed, or filed by the party. (
) Advisory will review and process suits to establish the liability under IRC of third parties paying or supplying funds for wages as provided for in the gation and Judgement Handbook. (
) Periodically Advisory will receive from Compliance Services Collection tions, Forms
, Statement of Liability of Lender, Surety or Other Person Withholding Taxes, that were mailed directly to the Service Center.

Periodically Advisory will receive from Compliance Services Collection Opera- tions, Forms 4219, Statement of Liability of Lender, Surety or Other Person for Withholding Taxes, that were mailed directly to the Service Center.
